subject: Re: American pronunciation
msgSnippet: ... Yes they can, mainly by the quantity (length) of the vowel in _surfer_ [ s3:f@], but also by quality.  In British accents the vowel in _suffer_ is
messageBody:
--- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, "Steve Bett" <sbett@l...> wrote:

> {can surfer and suffer be distinguished in a non-rhotic
> pronunciation?)

Yes they can, mainly by the quantity (length) of the vowel in
_surfer_ ["s3:f@], but also by quality. In British accents the
vowel in _suffer_ is typically more open and front ["s6f@], while
in American accents it is usually more close ["s@f@]. The
older transcription with a back unrounded vowel ["sVf@]
is however mostly an obsolete holdover now.

For phonetic symbols see: <http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/X-SAMPA>

/BP
